newsitem.title: HONG KONG: Shenzhen bank declines comment on share price rise.
newsitem.headline: Shenzhen bank declines comment on share price rise.

text.p: Shenzhen Development Bank Ltd declined to comment on Friday on a sharp rise in its domestic currency A share price.
The bank's A shares closed at 39.05 yuan, up 2.41 yuan from Thursday, despite rumours the bank was being investigated for share trading irregularities.
Traders said investors shrugged off the rumours after hearing of the bank's dividend plans, which will be confirmed at a shareholders' meeting on Monday.
The bank said on Monday it had found irregularities in its own stock trading in 1996, and its shares were suspended from trading that morning for the announcement.
A statement published in major financial newspapers said the bank was conducting investigations and would make further announcements as details became available.
The Shenzhen stock market was rife with rumours on Friday that authorities were investigating the bank for alleged insider trading conducted in 1996, brokers said.
There was also widespread talk that the bank could be fined and funds earned through improper trades seized, brokers said.
Officials at both the bank and the China Securities Regulatory Commission, the country's top securities watchdog, declined to comment on the speculation.
The bank spearheaded the bull-run in Shenzhen's A share market throughout 1996. Its stock price began 1996 at 3.16 yuan and ended the year at 16.52.
